docs.lead_paragraph: The words Gov. George E. Pataki uttered during his inaugural address on Wednesday were not that different from what he said throughout his campaign for re-election. It was, in essence, a patriotic pep talk, short on details, in which the governor asserted confidently that his administration had solved budget shortfalls before and would do so again.

headline.main: Taking the Oath, Then the Medicine; As Pataki Concedes Crisis, Critics Emerge Both Left and Right

docs.abstract: New York Gov George Pataki, beginning third term, finally admits state is in dire financial straits; Democrats are accusing him of having used of large reserves to avoid cutting spending before election and then misleading public about depth of budget shortfall; conservatives criticize him for allowing spending to grow sharply over last six years and prod him to return to austere budgeting policies of his first two years in office; Pataki, who ran campaign designed to appeal to left and right, now finds himself caught in crossfire; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Employees of the PolyMedica Corporation were warned by its chief executive yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation will begin questioning them in a fraud investigation. PolyMedica, a medical products maker in Woburn, Mass., is a target of criminal and civil inquiries by federal agencies and the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of Florida. The investigation, which is nearly two years old, is focusing on suspected abuses that include health care fraud within the government's Medicare program. In a memo to employees posted on PolyMedica's Web site, the chief executive, Samuel Shanaman, said, ''If you are contacted, it is our strong desire that you fully cooperate with federal investigators.'' The company's stock fell $3.46, to $27.62 a share.

headline.main: POLYMEDICA WORKERS TOLD TO EXPECT F.B.I. QUERIES

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials within the insurance industry and at large employers are welcoming the Bush administration's plan for sweeping changes in the Medicare program to accompany a new prescription drug benefit. But executives cautioned yesterday that their enthusiasm for any changes to Medicare hinged on adequate financing. Several officials said they expected that the influence of the new Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, a physician who is a Republican authority on health care, would greatly improve the chances that Congress would revise Medicare. President Bush has indicated that he wants to promote competition in the Medicare program when he proposes a prescription drug benefit.

headline.main: Drug Proposal For Medicare Is Welcomed With Wariness

docs.lead_paragraph: A long-delayed plan to have the federal government provide insurance for four construction companies against legal claims arising from their cleanup efforts at ground zero has been stalled by a request from the city government that it be covered, too. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Joe M. Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which has committed $1 billion to the plan, are scheduled to meet Tuesday to discuss the matter, city and federal officials said.

headline.main: City Request Stalls Insurance for 9/11 Cleanup

docs.abstract: Plan to have federal government provide insurance against legal claims for Bovis, Tully, AMEC and Turner, construction companies that conducted cleanup at ground zero, is stalled by request from New York City government that it be covered too; FEMA has committed $1 billion to coverage, but is balking at city's request to be included in plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 South Korean Leader Drafting a Compromise South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moon Hyun, is preparing a compromise proposal that would require both North Korea and the United States to accept concessions to resolve the standoff over the North's nuclear program, an aide said. A6 U.N.-Israeli Relations Failing The death of Iain Hook, a 54-year-old British supervisor for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency who was shot in the back by an Israeli soldier, has laid bare a breakdown of trust between the Israeli government and the United Nations. docs.lead_paragraph: McCORMACK - Clement Royal. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn the passing of our former Executive Vice President and Treasurer, Clem McCormack. Clem was a beloved friend whose contributions during his 16 years of service helped to build the strength of our company. Upon his retirement, the Board noted that his eminent career exhibited a special combination of sound business acumen with a faithful commitment to the health and human services community. We will miss him greatly. Our sincere condolences to his son, Mark, and daughters Maureen, Carol and Emily. William J. Flynn Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMACK, CLEMENT ROYAL

docs.lead_paragraph: An ambulance with lights flashing and siren screaming wheeled into the Weirton Medical Center here on Thursday afternoon, carrying a 30-year-old steelworker writhing in pain. Dr. Mitch Fuscardo, director of the emergency room, quickly determined that the man had a kidney stone blockage and that a surgeon was needed to remove the stone.

headline.main: Surgeons Explain Reasons for Their Walkout

docs.abstract: West Virginia surgeons taking leaves of absence to protest high malpractice insurance premiums say they will jump in to save lives, but not for other situations that may be merely painful or inconvenient; want reduction in their overall insurance costs, ceiling of $250,000 on claims of pain and suffering and help in getting higher payments for their work from health insurers; people can sympathize with surgeons, but are taken aback by such drastic step; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: State officials called on two dozen surgeons in the Northern Panhandle today to end a job action over malpractice costs as four hospitals cut staff hours and transferred more patients. So far, five patients have had to be sent elsewhere because of the dispute. Two were sent by the Weirton Medical Center today to a hospital in Ohio and two from Wheeling Hospital were taken to Pittsburgh hospitals on Wednesday. One patient who needed emergency surgery was taken 90 miles from Wheeling to Morgantown.

headline.main: West Virginia Officials Urge Doctors to End Their Walkout

docs.abstract: West Virginia officials call on two dozen surgeons in Wheeling and Weirton areas to end job action over malpractice costs; four hospitals cut staff hours and transfer patients (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Bush Defends His Tack In Handling North Korea President Bush brushed off signs that Asian nations differ sharply with him about how to handle the nuclear standoff with North Korea, arguing that Japan, South Korea and the European Union joined him in curtailing oil shipments to the country late last year and that the world would work together on the issue. A1 China's Role in the Koreas A fundamental economic and power shift is taking place in Northeast Asia. Faced with a looming crisis over North Korea's nuclear bomb program, South Korea sent an envoy to its most important economic partner: China. Until a decade ago, South Korea had no diplomatic relations with China, and would have turned to the United States. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign that its legal problems might intensify, the Tenet Healthcare Corporation said late today that it had received a subpoena from the Justice Department seeking documents related to certain Medicare payments. Tenet, one of the nation's largest hospital companies, is already being audited by the Department of Health and Human Services regarding the payments, which are known as outlier payments. But this is apparently the first time that the Justice Department has stepped in, which means that Tenet could face civil or criminal charges eventually.

headline.main: Tenet Receives a Subpoena From the Justice Department

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp says it has received subpoena from Justice Department seeking documents related to certain Medicare payments; will cooperate with US attorney's office, which wants documents by Feb 4 (M)
